Award.AbstractNarration: The aim of the proposal is to organize a conference on logic, more specifically descriptive set theory and model theory, and its applications. The lectures in the meeting will represent the highest quality work being done in the field. By bringing together major contributors to applications of descriptive set theory and model theory, the conference will help develop new avenues of cooperation and will help familiarize researchers with each others work. Goals of the project include, on the one hand, helping mathematicians learn to use tools coming from logic in their work and, on the other hand, familiarizing logicians with problems and ideas originating in other fields which may resonate with methods and ideas developed within logic. The young researchers whose participation in the meeting will be supported by this project will benefit by directly interacting with the best mathematicians in the field. Attendance in the conference will be a valuable component in their graduate and postgraduate education. The conference will take place at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign in the second half of April 2010.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Two International conferences on connections between logic and other areas of mathematics were organized at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign---the first one took place in September 4-5, 2010, the second one in September 3-4, 2011. Altogether 14 leading researchers gave invited talks. The speakers came from several foreign universities (located in Austria, Brazil, Canada, France, and the UK) and from a number of US universities. The talks represented the highest quality work done at the intersection of logic (primarily model theory and set theory) and other areas of mathematics such as ergodic theory, Banach space theory, operator theory, combinatorics, algebraic geometry, and topological dynamics. The conferences provided an excellent opportunity to deepen collaboration among the participants and to report the most recent findings in the very fast developing area of research. In addition to the invited speakers, the conference was attended by a substantial number of graduate students and postdoctoral fellows from several universities whose travel and local expenses were covered by the grant. The talks were also attended by local faculty and graduate students. For graduate students and postdocs who took part in the meetings, the participation in them became a valuable component of their current and future research efforts.
